interconnection.net_metering_details: Alabama has no state-mandated net metering policy. TVA offers limited buyback programs in parts of the state.
interconnection.fees: Varies by utility; TVA distributors may charge interconnection study fees

special_considerations.hoa_restrictions: No solar access law. HOAs may restrict or prohibit solar installations.
special_considerations.historic_districts: Local historic commissions may require certificate of appropriateness for solar in designated districts.
special_considerations.wind_load_requirements: Coastal areas (Mobile, Baldwin counties) require compliance with hurricane wind load standards per IBC/ASCE 7; design wind speeds up to 150 mph along the Gulf Coast.

licensing.license_type: Electrical Contractor license or unlimited Home Builder license for projects over $10,000

notes: Alabama is one of the least solar-friendly states with no net metering mandate, no state solar tax credit (residential ITC expired federally Jan 2026), and no solar access laws. Permits are handled at the county/municipal level with varying requirements. TVA territory covers parts of northern Alabama with different rules than Alabama Power territory.
